awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Vision care station for on-demand rapid examination of visual performance.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to significantly improve access to vision care for all Americans via a low-cost vision exam kiosk for supermarkets and pharmacies. A key technical component for reaching commercialization and scalability is the development of a contactless and autonomous eye scanner that accurately measures prescription numbers in under 10 seconds. The kiosk enables retailers that Americans already visit on average 20-30 times per year to offer instant vision exams and reports, eye prescriptions reviewed remotely by physicians, and access to high quality but affordable corrective eyewear. With 175 million Americans benefiting from vision correction, this solution could profoundly impact vision care across all communities. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project investigates the feasibility of a novel contactless eye refractor for use in a self-serve and autonomous vision care station for pharmacies and supermarkets. Eye scanning is done via the photo-refractive principle enabling autonomous ocular refraction in mere seconds. A key issue with leading photo-refractor configurations is the resulting drift stemming from gaze misalignment. Instead of refracting single positions in the visual field, the proposed novel configuration refracts the central and peripheral visual field simultaneously, thus guaranteeing the measurement of foveal refractive error. This novel configuration will use commonly available low-cost components and can be manufactured at a fraction of the cost of commercially autorefractors. A software model of the system will be used to efficiently optimize the configuration, after which the design will be built and tested. A physical model eye will be developed and used for testing to confirm the accuracy at a multitude of gaze angles and to confirm result-decoupling of gaze alignment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this Phase I project is to build and test the proposed gaze-independent photo-refractor (GIPR) to accurately measure prescription numbers from eyes. The GIPR is intended to improve on the performance of the standard photo-refraction technique (PR) found in commercial systems. One of the main challenges in auto-refractor measurement is that the result is coupled to the gaze-angle of the eye with respect to the device sensor. This can result in measurement drift and inaccurate readings with even slight gaze-misalignment. The primary aim of this project is to prove that the proposed GIPR configuration can eliminate the dependency on the subject's gaze angle with the device, and thus increase refractive error measurement accuracy and repeatability.

In conclusion, the project has successfully achieved all three objectives proposed in the Phase I project. This includes the development of a motorized mechanical eye model that accurately simulates a human eye's retinal reflex, the generation of an empirically derived library of pupil images, and the successful building, capture, and testing of the GIPR to extract power surfaces of the near periphery. We have confirmed that gaze-independence of the measurement is achieved and that the repeatability of the GIPR configuration was within the expected bounds, proving feasibility and commercial value of the technique. Besides demonstrating the feasibility of the GIPR technique, our results spurred the development of novel refraction-conversion algorithms, uncovered new opportunities in the domain of PR physics, and provided a foundation for the commercial readiness of 123 SEE's vision exam kiosk - the S1+.

The GIPR system is recommended for further study and development in Phase II with a significant number of human subjects. Additionally, the issues of stray light and back reflection artifacts in camera images will need to be addressed, the GIPR algorithm pipeline needs to be improved for increased measurement speed, and the prescription conversion techniques need to be optimized. Given the positive results and outcomes of the Phase I project, we propose that further research and development shall be made in a Phase II project to address the outstanding issues and further develop the GIPR system for commercial readiness.

 


Last Modified: 04/25/2023
Modified by: Matthias Hofmann
